696281FB993645D5A4B3A7864D3006BD.description: Ill-informed consumers and businesses are prone to underinvest or invest in wrong solutions if they do not possess an accurate understanding of threats and defenses.

D3A6CE7FA9C949FE8840CD29EBF56059.description: Consumers are often unaware of the value of their information that they exchange for an incentive from a company that uses their data for monetary purposes.

1EBC763D547646B2978EC168D378577A.description: In order to fully participate in today’s economy, consumers must give away their data and agree to a company’s terms that may conflict with their values.

362745DEF0724C99975885AD09F34D4E.description: Consumers are often driven by new functionality which is tangible while the security features of the product may only be understood or appreciated when the security fails.

2856ADEB00CC4004B2830501470D294D.description: Students will describe how economics shape the decisions of consumers.

2B6BCF32AE5E43FCB98BABF903354162.description: Whenever security depends on the weakest link in the global supply chain, firms do not prioritize in investing in security when they know that other players will not invest, leaving them vulnerable in any case.

39D1E5FD92D64984B6C6C719D87F09F3.description: Cybersecurity risks occur when outsourcing the production or maintenance of technology to third party sources that may have different security practices.

C94625ED26674F2286502C8E99B36563.description: Building security into the design at the onset results in better long term security when compared with bolting security onto existing systems.

4B2AD8638C874228A4CD892E0964C628.description: Bolting on security after the design is completed is often driven by short term incentives such as cost, speed to market, and features that are immediately transparent to potential customers.

FB9CA507224C4619A9087410FF67F853.description: Students will explain how economic forces influence the cybersecurity choices made by service providers and service designers.

0E501101B44D450EA97B09549248CEAF.description: When misaligned incentives arise the party making the security–efficiency trade-off is not the one who loses out when attacks occur.

1D8C75EEB4FB48C4BBAF32408461C912.description: Even in the event of a successful attack, the loss may or may not have lasting direct economic impact on the provider of the service.

E29F20B5DC8A4FF7ACC1BC3F092117C4.description: The lack of cybersecurity can result in major financial and reputational loss, but this loss only occurs after a successful attack.

ACB468859EDD479D9FB0A31AA4AC613C.description: The lack of cybersecurity can cause substantial economic losses; including the compromise of sensitive data, the modification of critical data, the improper behavior of a system, or the unavailability of a system.

0C8213D1FE4D42F0B08FFDE52503D1A8.description: Economic value typically measures gains achieved, not losses avoided.

3D548F121B054A74867465FC9C077F7C.description: Students will explain how misaligned incentives encourage businesses to under invest in cybersecurity.

F2AA9BCD3AAF49479B190B81CD666D6B.description: Measuring the economic value of cybersecurity is often an indirect process that relies on risk management trade- offs rather than direct benefits.

0A0CCBBD3E3F4BF79EA2526F45FB8423.description: When a government provides cybersecurity it can often lead to the reduction of privacy.

68E06136E4794E9AA1D7CE25A3B2C479.description: The combination of increasing power of new technology and the declining clarity and agreement on cybersecurity and privacy gives rise to problems concerning law, policy and ethics.

267E812A411246BE94387272D1765510.description: Nation states have various approaches to civil rights and privacy regarding cyber technology.

0A29060ECCF0499380D862E55D5772B4.description: Students will analyze how privacy concerns vary greatly in regards to societies, age, and socio-economic status.

254FEB265C374AAABFA96B712950D106.description: Cultural perceptions and priorities of security may differ between countries affecting how and which security measures are implemented.

CB48536BF57B4542A9F2D5695A065C4A.description: Citizens in cyber space can more readily form ideological communities which is impacting what it means to be a nation state.

FB7DBBFDD2B34F62B5BD6B541F4EDB58.description: Depending on the values of the entity, some will invest in research and development, while others invest in reverse engineering the work of others.

0971F8B15CAD43DEAA2C550F03F646B7.description: To ensure the safety of a nation’s critical infrastructure both public and private sectors are responsible for cybersecurity.

CACD5D1DDAE84E8DA50FC7E0E0B5209E.description: Past and current laws are insufficient to assign blame for taking action that make our systems more vulnerable or to punish an entity for cyber crimes.

112E66B119664751B935E2DA3B4465DC.description: Cybersecurity is impacted by the state of a political alliance between nation states.

AE17652FFC6F4475AE3B3E0EDC06514D.description: Nation states have various approaches to sovereignty, investment and deterrence regarding cyber technology.

FE0B8BF021B149769CF984863485D225.description: Students will describe how political ideologies, economic structures, social organizations, and cultural perceptions that impact cybersecurity.

4EC5381C08564EB7BD253C5BCC273FAF.description: Cybersecurity is global, transcending traditional boundaries, and is always evolving.

B143DC0549274A398369778EB6197657.description: The increasing dependence on the Internet and IoT devices introduces problems when these systems become unavailable.

78BDE36E5F0F4DA7B6F4730B8121DD80.description: The Internet and IoT devices create new vulnerabilities an adversary can exploit.

D025680A341E4DC4BE42A43D9B25D576.description: The “Internet of Things,” benefits our daily lives by providing easier access to information, the ability to offload menial tasks, and coordinate necessary information.

9CEA3BB6ED4E4AE9BA5AD727050DAA3E.description: The Internet has evolved to include new types of devices and the “Internet of Things."

BC1EE91AF9604F0798E8D5B129AFA509.description: Early government policies discouraged the use of encryption to build secure networks.

30505E9A9E45418FB01ADEF35DA99C42.description: Security was not seen as a concern until much of the “infrastructure” for computer networks was in place.

70EC1E6D77CE463DAAE582D4FC986846.description: The Internet provides global connectivity and is not structured around national boundaries.

A32B7EFD51F546A2B91C20CA959AE39D.description: Students will explain how the idea of the open internet led us to new innovations that impact our daily lives and our security.

A117AF4E6D094D0CB85D75FE658B8865.description: Cybersecurity events have led to the development of various cybersecurity career paths and various needs in order to prepare people for these new types of jobs.

09555E4C86374582BD1A13C147A2672F.description: The emergence of advanced persistent threats (APTs) have caused changes in the way individuals and companies are secured and who is involved in securing them.

33445907E7E943B8943FE8C1B8895C65.description: A loss of availability has disrupted critical business functions.

2FC7A26DCA754E0F96A234F4897CBF40.description: The violation of system integrity can alter the behavior of critical infrastructure.

ED8970B4C3C24889A74633C1C671C32F.description: The loss of confidentiality is a critical factor in warfare.

06A543E9E22647B4B6D2E3BA0B422747.description: Events in cyber warfare and cybercrime escalated the need for increased cybersecurity efforts.

A43933DF0AE1445B8B733CA57C010A7A.description: As technology progressed so did the use of both disinformation and information security in national, societal, and personal gain, often at the expense of another party.

35EC0ACA2B3D4875A1D0F794717C577C.description: Information campaigns were used and considered vital throughout history.

FE366A1C53A749C4BCB474E8E5F782B9.description: Students will summarize and interpret the impact of cybersecurity ideas and events on the evolution of the field.

FDA131F0E40B4A0CAC5BA24C755D89D8.description: Cybersecurity shapes and is shaped by significant historical ideas and events.

2FCCAB1A9F0B47FDA8B991A9E1258CE4.description: Cryptography does not solve operational challenges and cryptography alone is not a solution in a decentralized network.

CE8A1E0AEEC747A2B0B41E478AC0C29C.description: Certificate authorities play a role in asserting the identities.

3C3D5232B4EA4956AD2340AC66322A62.description: Cryptography can be used to identify the creator of a message and show a message was not modified in transit (hash function).

7D30EE865C174C5B87BF0FB5F992E956.description: Cryptography can be used to prevent imposters and protect data so only authorized entities can view it.

3A988FE46104440AA9CE3A0DA446F788.description: Network vulnerabilities can result in the loss of availability by directing the sender to an invalid destination or sending data over a path where it can be dropped.

7CEF53A6C06A4898B2001C17374A3FC4.description: Network vulnerabilities can result in the loss of integrity if data is sent to an imposter acting as a “man-in-the-middle” or when data is sent over a path where it can be changed.

C84E6D4F725F4BBBB3D1CA0CF3B03B0A.description: Incorrect assumptions about the network can result in the loss of confidentiality by sending data to an imposter or sending data over a path where it can be observed.

7BF03ECB8D6A4ABFB4F9D2BF6B250747.description: Internet communication between a sender and receive relies on a number of systems that are not controlled by the sender or receiver. This can include the hardware and software at the sender and the sender’s edge network. It includes a number of supporting systems such as the DNS and certificate authorities, and any number of intermediate networks. It can also include the receiver’s edge network as well as the hardware and software at the receiver.

20749CE80C0A45349D1E7E070B0F419E.description: There are risks and mitigations associated with open systems like the Internet.

775F8B497E8941A886AB1693293CF197.description: Students will be able to explain how the decentralized and dynamic nature of networked systems create the potential for a system to fail or behave incorrectly due a component the designer didn’t even know existed.

17C72724215D4B96ADC0D87B1A027381.description: Hardware itself may act in unintended ways and an adversary is seeking to find and exploit these unintended behaviors.

EDBA85950D6D415A94F970A4155651EC.description: Changes in software code are common and those introduced by an adversary are often not easily detected.

F501016B4A9948008FF56712BF4BF18E.description: Software changes could come from an adversary that intentionally inserts code to meet the goals of the adversary.

15FA8CE00E1E4B148CE22C3CA54C9C97.description: Software is frequently updated to correct both functional errors and security problems.

B2F9952A22D24E3D9BD1D00305C9EBD3.description: Students will be able to explain how the logical malleability of software and hardware can allow an adversary to change a system to meet the adversary’s goals rather than the system’s original objective.

62897642A5E74B0E84E9D36F21B52E9A.description: Adversaries are self-interested agents whose behavior evolves and adapts in response to their environments and other actors in the system.

E7D135CE7ABF4FA6BC6A6F92488492ED.description: The steps in an attack are footprinting, scanning, enumeration, network mapping, gaining access, privilege escalation, implant, and hiding tracks.

7083938D6044427E8F8571F3D426051F.description: Adversaries employ strategic reasoning, including where, when, and how they might attack, as well as tactics for evading detection.

5829D106D8504565895F817E61249097.description: Students will be able to describe how the presence of an adversary necessitates that cybersecurity risk is emergent and complex.

863CA0B2C9BB4A11AFEBD908DD9E56E9.description: The participants or agents of a system (human agents, including or especially adversaries, in this case) are self-learning and change their behavior based on the outcomes of the previous experience.

155ECE819DEB41F397BCFE7F7EE0D9A7.description: The behavior of the system is emergent and changes with time. The same input and environmental conditions do not always guarantee the same output.

4222BBDAE43E41378627001AF7C6146C.description: The behavior or output of cybersystems cannot be predicted simply by analyzing the parts and inputs of the system.

7CC09B78A8174B66A839CC496836C7A2.description: The behavior of complex systems has unpredictable output, i.e., it is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, or other types of interactions between the parts or between a given system and its environment.

BF1320F7075849FBA1A8867DE48622CD.description: A complex system is a system composed of many parts, which may interact with each other, where the interactions produce properties that its parts do not have.

9A8693FFF19B4A6E94AB27D4B75F0AAE.description: Students will be able to explain how cyberspace is a very large, complex system of cybersystems that include hardware, software, social, economic, and political components.

4D85A2B1D5234083A590A229AAE8CA2E.description: There are factors that necessitate cybersecurity risk as emergent and complex: the presence of an adversary, the logical malleability of computers, and the decentralized and distributed nature of networked systems.

22F4928B4D6348C1A0C3F9E0541A7733.description: The level of protection is a function of the attack occurring and the effects of the attack should it succeed.

126FD01A40ED49E0BB82BFD6E8DF9DF4.description: If the data or resources cost less or are of less value than their protection, adding security mechanisms is not cost effective.

FDD44B92400E4D9386B55E8EEC3C62E3.description: The outcome of a risk assessment should prioritize what needs to be remediated.

F0CCB22241A54A9F99A3564F50F31351.description: Students will understand the trade-offs between cybersecurity benefits and the total cost of cybersecurity protections.

63978A5EFFF14385990A86B1D31CFC96.description: Penetration testing, also called pen testing or ethical hacking, is the practice of testing a computer system, network or web application to find security vulnerabilities that an attacker could exploit.

2650578B453D4D009170F23B5AD578E4.description: Not all vulnerabilities can be exploited and not all vulnerabilities need to be mitigated.

6DBABF0CECE3438DB24BD51942CCFE91.description: There are various automated vulnerability scanning tools, which are used for pinpointing vulnerabilities and providing remediation for these vulnerabilities.

AB5B300C43BC43DA922017A9C8FB9272.description: Known vulnerabilities can be found in databases that collect, maintain, and disseminate information.

396AC00C66314ACC9172848C56CD617E.description: Vulnerability assessment identifies known vulnerabilities on the system.

489EE38C8E15477283406E6713550A79.description: Students will be able to conduct standard security testing and assessments.

5489ED6A6AD8435A8A17ECD924866B19.description: There are risks and solutions associated with closed/proprietary systems.

543B3D6D2AD0409BAB40C8271964DD02.description: Bad actors in cyberspace are characterized by their resources, capabilities/techniques, motivations, and aversion to risk.

005BC0DCF1944B699F3275168691D243.description: Threats originate from internal (insider) and external sources such as nation states, multinational criminal organizations, and hacktivists/terrorists.

E9DD78C64C264300850D56D754689DBF.description: Students will create a threat model and evaluate the trade-offs associated with defending against different threat sources.

35AB25A483EB48DF8EC9D6C86620C413.description: Risks to information assets are a function of the likelihood that a threat source will exploit a vulnerability, and the resulting damage if the attack is successful.

4D15DF03C6C644F09513D88B47706459.description: Information assets are characterized and prioritized according to their need to be kept confidential, unchanged, and/or available, and their criticality/sensitivity.

ACE45B2F16004C05AA8C428CBA5A2AD5.description: Students will be able to identify and prioritize the protection of information assets.

5512486E43894CD0A35DB3851AC3B303.description: Attacks arise when threats exploit vulnerabilities.

D46A12F1CD3F434A95D9F0881B098733.description: A threat is anything that can exploit a vulnerability, intentionally or accidentally, and obtain, damage, or destroy an asset.

597E723A33AD48338E5AA9FAA2AA2053.description: A vulnerability is a weakness or gap in a security program that can be exploited by threats to gain unauthorized access to an asset.

71216A471259431EA6DD9B452F30F883.description: Students will be able to differentiate between threats, vulnerabilities, and attacks.

9624336D7C5F47638F689DF2CBB5E1F8.description: Cybersecurity risk is a measure of the potential damage or loss a vulnerability could cause weighed against the likelihood an adversary will exploit the vulnerability.

7C515ADCB6D14EB48FAB57FBE314666A.description: The final stage of the kill chain is actions on the objective. Once adversaries have control, persistence, and ongoing command and communication, they will act upon their motivation in order to achieve their goal(s), e.g., data exfiltration, destruction of critical infrastructure, to deface web property, or to create fear or the means for extortion.

76937304168D46B68A5A95629576A736.description: Command and control is the sixth phase of the cyber kill chain. With malware installed, attackers now own both sides of the connection: their malicious infrastructure and the infected machine and can now actively control the system. Attackers will establish a command channel in order to communicate and pass data back and forth between the infected devices and their own infrastructure.

8124EB15FF3C4E7AB099859598C61CC3.description: The fifth stage is installation where attackers install a remote access trojan or backdoor on the victim system in order to conduct further operations, such as maintaining access, persistence and escalating privileges.

6D7730741EE74964A4EA97AD92ECD632.description: Exploitation is the fourth phase where the code is triggered exploiting vulnerable applications or systems.

23D45EACEB8B4C148029818497E792E9.description: The third phase is delivery, which is the transmission of the weapon to the target environment using vectors like email attachments, phishing, websites, and removable media.

D0CA1776E6DA4DDD9C5F92191CE04F4E.description: Weaponization is the second stage. Based on the information obtained through reconnaissance, the adversary will tailor their toolset to meet the specific requirements of the target network. This often includes coupling remote access with an exploit into a deliverable payload.

3E7F969B6A33473FA5293133989FB9EE.description: Reconnaissance is the first stage in the attack lifecycle, where adversaries gather public information about the target, and scan their networks to identify how best to plan their attack.

5DFB80A0F15D4676B31208A1F6EA09F5.description: The term “kill chain” refers to the structure—or seven stages—of a cyberattack.

01EA3F3C106C49E58A0A92F1881D2E71.description: Students will analyze how the cybersecurity attack lifecycle/kill chain is essential to adversarial thinking.

5E1F05F249294883AC23205C92A23C88.description: Incident response includes provisioning for the confidentiality, integrity and availability of cyber systems under attack by adversaries.

A64BB1A0910C49969386D5237C2CD2B8.description: Cyber systems are susceptible to attack from human adversaries.

7AD585B9490747C897ADA8CF3B970746.description: The manner in which an adversary carries out their intentions (sometimes called attacks) is related to their capabilities and the resources they can bring to bear.

859768676FAF4FB9BD6C0C752BCC29D4.description: The intentions of adversaries can be classified as theft, disclosure, disruption, destruction, and/or subversion.

BEC8E82B84A54D51ADE6960457EE3405.description: Students will explain how intentional attacks can adapt to defenses and cause a system to fail.

DCC57FDA319C4D01B0ACE7A34DBDF8BC.description: Natural event and unintentional errors typically do not adapt in response to defenses.

79165B1B4CCA4DD4A08D0093946BD9C4.description: Disaster planning includes prevention, detection, and response and recovery.

76AB528EFD8F4C60AA6A83D183FFF7F7.description: Disaster planning includes provisioning for the confidentiality, integrity and availability of cyber systems during natural disasters.

2B799DEC014740EFA85898867D3FF33F.description: Cyber systems are susceptible to disruption and destruction from natural disasters; for example, flooding, earthquakes, and hurricanes.

B748932FBB454C8AB3151C2D87F73C18.description: Students identify the ways in which natural events and unintentional errors can cause a system to fail.

2E31A22E48A9421AB133A9BAB8259C84.description: Adversarial thinking is the process of reasoning about how opposing forces could prevent a system from meeting both its functional and security goals.

052981AA139F4921BB02C23E926DC8FA.description: Social engineering is one of the most widely used techniques in which an adversary compromises a system by convincing a human to violate the security policies in a way that enables the adversary to gain an advantage.

6F1F7A32C3C840BA8F1F7E15C708C774.description: Human users of the system have their own conscious and unconscious objectives that can undermine cybersecurity protections and policies.

AE07A4F00D964FC984B80B77AC521F40.description: Students will understand how social behaviors and human factors impact the cybersecurity of a system design.

19098D74A71446979E640FC951B0B64B.description: Change introduces new forms of failure.

9BBFE1062B45496197704E39019424AC.description: Events ranging from natural disasters to unintentional errors can result in cybersecurity failures.

BBD5E139ACFF4A1D8B25F1CD58DA5960.description: Human operators have dual roles: as producers and defenders against failure.

653F79F8F8A74B40BD7E3FB80ED83A22.description: Security is only as strong as the weakest link and is not limited to human actors.

A14B957843E84A2AA107104121312DD8.description: Students will identify and explain how different system components impact the cybersecurity of a system design.

6A4D18C0C66D467B860A80257D8E2518.description: Security is a characteristic of systems and not system components.

2F4627440F4A4BABAB8456CC2C665FE2.description: Given the complexity of cybersystems, there are limits to how much entities can control their functioning and success of their policies.

EF42D93DCA714885AFFDD1336957B93A.description: Product failure is deceptively difficult to understand given that it depends on the intrinsic properties of each part, what it’s made of, how those materials respond to varying and unanticipated conditions, and how customers use a product.

1B15726E20DE44D397B1CADBA51BE178.description: System failures are characterized by a series of actions or behaviors that are normally isolated or self-contained, but become consequential due to interconnected impact.

0C79CFE6C49B4C3D86DD30EDC3838FE4.description: In complex systems, failures are rarely the result of one individual's problem or behavior; catastrophe requires multiple failures.

EBC0E2B9264B4ED2B2BA381D09E54025.description: Students will explain how complexity impacts the failure of cybersystems.

FE1CA6456B67482EBAC35371124AE48A.description: The internet is a prime example of a complex system in that it is a large and complex system composed of multiple, dispersed, independent systems.

E1832ACEC21447D7B5DBB799E0E8CC82.description: Complex systems typically have input from many sources and are highly changeable.

20A06071FED9475A8DCED3DA24674DB4.description: A complex system is a system composed of many components which may interact with each other.

386F943B2DA345809E89CB812B47588D.description: Students will explain how cybersystems are complex systems.

C5406B9766494794AEB9856FB07A7808.description: Adversity comes from anyone or anything where the end result differs from that intended by the system designer and user.

DA77F6CB2A9143528438B9587B059395.description: By targeting trusted resources attackers can control devices and wholeheartedly manipulate users.

1234354CA8F54A5D9483E12D50017A53.description: The consequences of unintentional faults or malicious attacks could have severe impact on human lives and the environment.

999C680A08F445508FA3C004838E980B.description: Vulnerabilities may allow adversaries to interfere with connected devices.

3718BD224D1343EFB642208A2CCCF69E.description: Increased industry connectivity will cause increased attacks from adversaries such as cyber criminals, disgruntled employees, terrorists, organized crime, and nation states.

F8E56AB458844AA3808B4290058D96A5.description: A smart grid is an electrical grid which includes a variety of operation and energy measures including smart meters, smart appliances, renewable energy resources, and energy efficient resources.

6390BD0C9ECD449DB3E7B5DCC7B409CA.description: Industries that employ CPS include energy management, health care, manufacturing, transportation, telecommunications, infrastructure, and military.

B04795A3EFDF47AC9141D642223694F4.description: A cyber-physical system (CPS) is a mechanism that is controlled or monitored by computer-based algorithms, tightly integrated with the Internet and its users.

6DBF7BD7DC174ECD87E3969CD7F09555.description: Students will predict how physical systems that rely on software may be vulnerable to future attacks.

C6C08692E71E4EBCA216F8AAE725BE25.description: Software vulnerability examples that resulted in a loss of availability such as DDoS attacks on websites (Mirai botnet), ransomware that locks outs access to data (WannaCry, Petya, NotPetya), Telephony Denial of Service (attacks on 911).

823E0874806544F4BFEEEC4CE3804690.description: Software vulnerabilities examples that resulted in a loss of integrity such as man in the middle attacks (many examples), compromise industrial control systems (i.e. Stuxnet), vehicle control systems (Jeep Cherokee hack), and medical devices (Medtronic infusion pumps).

A7AC6B96B5B8464881C44CE8E4D194AB.description: Software vulnerability examples that resulted in a loss of confidential data and corresponding monetary losses for the victims including intellectual property theft and ability to directly access financial data.

302668569A384142A17CE6C2B7B2EA56.description: Software vulnerability examples that resulted in a loss of confidential data including breaches of credit information (Equifax), healthcare information (Anthem), government records (OPM data breach), home assistants (Amazon Echo hacks), baby monitors (many examples), and fitness tracker data (mapping military bases).

0ACE3C86041741B7B10E28B4DC9B7FED.description: Students will identify historical consequences of software and hardware vulnerabilities, e.g., power outages, death, theft of trade secrets from other sovereign nations.

375E2A9C64854DEA8358E6696F2152B0.description: Software and Hardware (or Systems) are everywhere which increasingly makes it foundational in civilization.

E3234E280CEE4047B7A4340B595EC8E3.description: Dynamic analysis is a process in which external tools analyze the execution of code in order to automatically identify potential security vulnerabilities.

5BC8BB5314674338B864B4899FB1C212.description: Managing vulnerability reports, patching and patch distribution is a key part of software security.

49335578864140CA846CDFE2013128CB.description: A zero-day vulnerability is a software security flaw that is unknown to people who should be responsible for patching or fixing the flaw. Zero-day attacks are cyber attacks utilizing one or multiple zero-day vulnerabilities.

68C72DD9893A4BF28CC7CAACCB73DF0C.description: Security vulnerability reports such as Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) and Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) are publicly available for software systems and should be monitored, or subscribe to their alerts.

4B51868B2903437E8E7455F7240FA351.description: A security analysis is a process that is used to verify a program meets a specified list of security requirements.

BF7CA0E0DA0C4A5D831677E2A4ECFF1D.description: Students will describe the process of validating that software remains secure through its lifecycle.

1EC778128B7946D594B8B20DEFB0FE8C.description: Development tools and Integrated software Development Environments (IDE)s provide static analysis tools to check for some types of insecure code such as identifying potential buffer overflows.

EE20BCDF94C947EBB9E9D4D44A56B47E.description: Static analysis of software is a process in which external tools analyze the code and automatically identify potential security vulnerabilities such as potential buffer overflows.

9EEE9D429B4A4FFE83852C1F69FF927B.description: Input validation is code added to the program that verifies input provided by an external source is the type of input expected and will be processed correctly.

BA9ADCA5852F4522992890992F7C770F.description: Students will identify the processes of developing secure software.

8551CE78B99A4714A6B18AD7854C3EEB.description: A software vulnerability can occur when external components that don’t meet the security policy requirements are connected to the system.

BC511C7B0EB347C9B05B7623AF46180A.description: Changes to the environment can cause software to no longer meet the security policy and secure software must include considerations for how to implement future changes (e.g., credentials, algorithms, and patching code to correct bugs and errors).

D4284C49FDCC4B26B9EF6C518EDC03A0.description: A software vulnerability may exist when cryptographic functions are not implemented properly or when the cryptographic functions are assumed to provide more security than the algorithm provides.

3091CA8541124A4C9871D26BB7BD33D0.description: A software vulnerability may exist when data is allowed to include unauthorized control instructions that dictate how the program should behave and thus can cause the program to behave in a way that violates the security policy.

08285308160C4A94BF76605756DBA36A.description: A buffer overflow is an anomaly where a program, while writing data to a buffer, overruns the buffer's boundary and overwrites adjacent memory locations, and how this can be used as an entry point by an attacker to violate security policy.

D613E704319B4F26A89B3C0E683677FB.description: Injection attacks occur when an external source such as a user provides input that causes a program to behave in ways that violate the security policy by executing harmful commands.

10F8ADB33FF540DDB08B14B96815DA2F.description: Students will describe common security-related software vulnerabilities.

5C00F66435C948709E061320676918E1.description: Security vulnerabilities in software are weaknesses in a system's design, implementation, or operation and management that could be exploited to violate the system's security policy.

79E6091379F34ADDA84E8BE431261775.description: Students will identify examples of fail-safe in cybersecurity, i.e., a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause no or minimal harm to other equipment, the environment or to people, and provide recovery opportunities.

1C4A3A199BB8415D8ACA9649F07DADBE.description: The hardware design can require the device to disable itself if physically tampered with.

A6A17642B0404471B179B58B6B667BFA.description: Students will identify hardware security issues related to an adversary physically gaining access to a device.

BE01CE6BCBF145B3B11AB252CFA170A5.description: Physical security measures can be used to deny unauthorized access to facilities, equipment and resources and to protect personnel and property from damage or harm.

B465B9FC4EFF46BF80D28F3A80E75170.description: The hardware design, manufacturing and supply chain can be attacked by malicious actors, nation states, competitors, and organized crime.

C3F5FBFD75F343D0BACE074A95223660.description: Hardware itself consists of many components and supply chain management attempts to ensure each component as well as the composition of these components meets an overall security policy.

703C6F38DD7543C9B7CC7CA3D1EA67EA.description: Students will describe the process of developing secure hardware and validating that it is secure through its lifecycle.

9C4B8827EDCC4BE996A8CCAA38D7B855.description: Hardware vulnerabilities can also be due to weaknesses in the implementation of algorithms.

66CB18B312664673808D97EFCB9F8932.description: General classes of side channel attacks include attacks such as: timing attacks, power-monitoring attacks, electromagnetic attacks, data remanence attacks.

7BDCCA1FA6734E4C92FC4BE0956E2636.description: A side channel attack is based on information gained from the use of an algorithm or computer system, rather than weaknesses in the algorithm itself (e.g. cryptanalysis and software bugs).

573B5F186DC04F3EAF7D2792552D966D.description: Manufacturing backdoors are used for malware or other penetrative purposes; backdoors aren’t limited to software and hardware, but they also affect embedded radio-frequency identification (RFID) chips and memory.

272EE06C1A5F426E8CC76B9B0E3D4E3B.description: A backdoor is a method, often secret, of bypassing normal authentication or encryption in a computer system, a product, or an embedded device (e.g. a home router) to secure remote access.

E65B0D31AC6A4CFD821E2B9072271CD2.description: Students will identify some common hardware-related vulnerabilities.

917E37DBBB844CD5917D1E8083D765D1.description: Tamper resistant hardware aims to detect if someone attempts to modify them and aim to become non-functional if that occurs. For example, credit card readers at a store are designed to be no longer usable if someone physically opens the credit card reader system.

705D7D3EC1324A00A08A9F54F72F9E9E.description: Hardware is the base level component of systems that are critical to telecommunications, health, US economic system, and national defense.

8D26B70180A843358FDC6857948DD8DA.description: External hardware devices include monitors, keyboards, mice, printers, scanners, routers, switches, servers, IoT devices industrial control systems, and security cameras.

79F0FA79BA684C10A1FCF484C5B34C75.description: Internal hardware devices include CPUs, motherboards, hard drives, memory, and internal peripherals such as a CD-ROM drive, CD-R drive, or internal modem.

09A0555307B24935B2A34B717564937B.description: Students will convey that computer hardware refers to the physical parts of a computer and related devices.

0D6A214DFA5C412FA3D20D4B110D658E.description: Hardware security protects the machine and peripheral hardware from theft and from electronic intrusion and damage.

6800A8EA9DC44331B6B8366E741186CC.description: The overall system can be manipulated to act incorrectly if there is a vulnerability in the hardware, the software, the interface between them, or any combination of those.

471A74B9EEFA4D23B96504D4CF5ACB7C.description: Hardware ultimately relies on the software instructions to accomplish its task and even if the hardware operates perfectly, it will not perform the desired function if the software directs it to execute the wrong instructions. In other words, the hardware may be able to correctly apply the brakes in a vehicle when instructed to do but it will not prevent a vehicle crash if the software is too slow in deciding when to apply the brakes.

90EC9D9AE07F4AF194ED2D65F25356E1.description: Software ultimately relies on the physical hardware to accomplish its task and even if the software is written perfectly, it will not perform the desired function if the hardware fails to behave as expected.

23C4FDF62B394E5885E992BC5A0B5C01.description: Embedded software is computer software, written to control machines or devices that are not typically thought of as computers, commonly known as embedded systems.

075CB8B59E1749FB9705693F85ADB3C3.description: Embedded software can be built directly into the physical device so the instructions on how a device will behave are physically part of the device and often cannot be changed without changing the hardware itself.

9774DF94C71B4EC799DB35AE1A73F9F0.description: Software can be written in low level machine specific instructions that tell the CPU, memory, and other devices exactly what to do (e.g. add memory locations one and two and store the result in memory location.

D2B3FB9070034B60B15811CB9273BBFC.description: Software can be written in high level languages such as Python, C, Perl, Java and the high level software is converted into low level instructions that tell the CPU, memory, and other devices exactly what to do.

A37B9857CEE74D72B063926E67C4D7CA.description: Software includes programs written to run on servers, laptops, and traditional computers. Computing devices accomplish no tasks without running software that tells it what to do.

8AAE5A17774E417894782E25F18A6218.description: Malware, short for malicious software, is any software intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.

4F32D06229954320AB71786DE27D83F9.description: Software instructions may manipulate data, manipulate physical systems or manipulate both. For example, software in a vehicle may record the vehicle speed and send it to a cloud storage system, other software may cause the brakes to be physically applied and reduce the speed, and still other software may both record and manipulate the vehicle speed.

580EC38411DE4CCCB1C7C66C3531C8E9.description: Neither hardware or software is useful without the other.

4C5667718E524BD28C13428747E01DC2.description: Software is a set of instructions that execute on hardware and are designed to achieve some objective on a physical device.

7870BADD1E7D4CFB8FF12E02B1BA012A.description: Students will identify how hardware and software work together in complex ways to achieve an overall objective.

B61F925FB4A64B318B158399AEC09091.description: Systems consist of a combination of hardware and software that together achieve some objective and security requires integration of both.

CF8BD27FF3C24B96977FD9597AAF329C.description: Digital Signatures are a type of electronic signature that encrypts documents with digital codes that are particularly difficult to duplicate.

C2D9BE0DA55D418AA4A31F5005ACE1A4.description: Secret messages encipher the message with the recipient's public key, are sent, and then the recipient can decipher it using their private key.

7FDE295A719E40D1B93BABDAA610D147.description: Public key encryption uses a key pair - a private key known only to the entity and a cryptographically linked public key that can be shared with anyone.

DE19738AB31142AF84FC5B23822290F1.description: Public key encryption does not require the sender and receiver to share the same key.

FFCB839706C7441B88495B5C6C72DB88.description: Students will employ public key (asymmetric) encryption and explain how it works.

B97FFE4667074F00ABFB4C98C8F04B11.description: A shift cipher is susceptible to a statistical ciphertext-only attack.

B1FC5DDB93834771960B0AEFD4B172A5.description: A substitution cipher changes characters in the plaintext to produce the ciphertext.

62F5F1F6083741EA944BF40BE33D12F4.description: Anagramming is a way to attack a transposition cipher. It uses tables of n-gram frequencies to identify common n-grams.

D613AEAECD7247ADA1D1105ED5FB3EE4.description: In transposition ciphers the letters are not changed they are rearranged. The set of encryption functions E is simply the set of permutations of m, and the set of decryption functions D is the set of inverse permutations.

6CCA40B54E254BD8B2EF76AEFFAF9E1A.description: There are two basic types of symmetric ciphers: Transposition ciphers that diffuse the data in the plaintext and substitution ciphers that replace the data in the plaintext.

AF5B7C6F6A894B2AAE33889204C5AD3A.description: Students will practice symmetric cryptosystems to send a message and explain how they work.

8C3B95ABE2C4437190CACB32330416E5.description: Certificate authorities (CAs) issue digital certificates that validate the ownership.

59A9CD0A316A464E9685EF31D40DCB75.description: Hash functions can be used for checking whether a file was corrupted.

778EC81D878644A6AA176B02C8150D32.description: Public key encryption, which is asymmetric, is an encryption method that is widely used because of the enhanced security associated with its use.

F1BBE36463B64F649727C891FD4789C5.description: Symmetric encryption is a method of encryption involving one key for encryption and decryption.

97397E18ED964A9A84F23C9A30E6F734.description: The primary goal of cryptography is to keep enciphered information secret.

E5DE1537B287429489D0E963A0AB85D9.description: Ciphertext is encrypted text. Plaintext is what you have before encryption, and ciphertext is the encrypted result.

ABFD5D4E253F4DF3BAED83B505B521F1.description: Decryption is the process of taking encoded or encrypted text or other data and converting it back into text that you or the computer can read and understand.

826854911A7A40AF8655B72AB1B9B69D.description: Encryption is the process of encoding a message or information in such a way that only authorized parties can access it and those who are not authorized cannot.

BE01619E6F5749C59C5366B7B3D05937.description: Cryptographic algorithms, also known as ciphers, which are mathematical functions used in the process of encryption and decryption.

D857DD706DF348AA9BAAA2AF42431E93.description: Cryptanalysis is the breaking of codes.

F88546E31CBA47D497B663D7DBF4E2ED.description: Cryptography comes from two Greek words meaning "secret writing" and is the art and science of concealing meaning.

2D5DB0A56BA54779AA4F8D915D1C596B.description: Students will define cryptography and explain how it is used in data security.

386BCDC9BA5B45C5B323B4217419DA9D.description: Cryptography techniques are necessary to keep data private and secure, and evolve with changes in technology.

798491F72E964B269813025155F8D6A4.description: Failure to protect data can be due to faulty authentication, faculty authorization, and/or faulty access control.

2A728700CC0642179EC5D022BFA8769B.description: Access Control is the process of enforcing the required security for a particular resource.

B8B1A6A4534B4960A1FBE0044F0E23C0.description: Groups, Roles, Privileges and Permissions are used to manage authorization.

57E9741C29504F35A1054EAEA4F7725D.description: Authorization is the process of establishing if the authenticated user is permitted to have access to, and/or act on a resource.

1EB917F722AB47038A6AF71C4FE62300.description: The strength of a password is a function of length, complexity, and unpredictability.

0EEE193901D8433FBC26D38C369A63DF.description: Passwords and passphrases are a common form of authentication.

62A25FBECC0F4C86977185A65EFCDF88.description: Identity management includes authentication, access control, sometimes coordination across different domains, and management of the credentials throughout the lifecycle.

51C8D8AE960F456BB81E01326E561EAF.description: Authentication can be done using multiple factors, something you have, something you know, something you do, and something you are. (E.g., have = card, know=password, do=sign, walk, are=fingerprint, retina)

E0CB4C0BAD534BB5A6AE8AB4552E6664.description: Authentication requires a database of information.

92AFF314A3AF4D5A99E2EE24C09A7C00.description: Authentication is a process by which you verify that someone is who they claim they are.

ABF0A51212A94655AB4285F330DA2710.description: Students will evaluate and recommend technical controls that can be used to secure data.

31656548372447858B8507C9F500F4D3.description: Commonly used physical controls include: limited entry points, redundant systems, and surveillance cameras.

7112EAE5D7DD4C03AF1FBFBB825DA6CB.description: Physical security is an important part of defense in depth. To provide comprehensive physical security, multiple systems and processes must work together, like perimeter security, access control, and process management.

25C96685523D4F77AAC603B4FB0E6109.description: Physical security controls are means and devices to control physical access to sensitive information and to protect the availability of the information

410F6407A82B4C14A60FA6594B37FDDA.description: Students will identify physical controls that are used to secure data.

B78F59E6FADA428DB65CE8085419DFEC.description: An Acceptable Use Policy is a set of rules applied by the owner, creator or administrator of a network, website, or service, that restrict the ways in which the network, website or system may be used and sets guidelines as to how it should be used.

6801E388E99B419DA6268BB8336EC43F.description: There are also state cybersecurity laws. One example are the Data Breach Disclosure laws that exist in 48 states, but differ by state. Another example is CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act), which was signed into law in 2018 to extend the privacy rights of the citizens of California.

04C3B65D59564A8D8A7F237004959FB7.description: CFAA (Computer Fraud and Abuse Act) prohibits accessing a computer without authorization, or in excess of authorization.

EA6FA7A8677846898B1548255EE94076.description: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) is United States legislation that provides data privacy and security provisions for safeguarding medical information.

73F79127623D4EFEAE7D40DCBCE4B94F.description: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) is a set of regulations designed to give citizens in the European Union more control over their personal data.

7D9496223BA5449681310234FBF4725D.description: Laws are in place to protect the disclosure and misuse of financial, personal, and private information.

2BC80501C7FA460D9C8CCFB75C0CEA24.description: Policies can be introduced and enforced at the local, state, and national levels.

8B7A2517C9CE443CA468F7345B232376.description: Students will compare and contrast data protection legislation, policies, and procedures that have been or are being introduced all over the world to protect personal data.

708126A22296481381B5D4569BF2F65E.description: Data Security uses non-technical and technical controls and techniques to protect data that is being processed, transmitted and stored.

A77F9EF8EF7D4E28BC07EC0F51A2E92F.description: Data confidentiality is about protecting data against unintentional, unlawful, or unauthorized access, disclosure, or theft.

EF1AB0E1E16040508C42F89D9DA422ED.description: Origin integrity means the original data is trustworthy, and its source is trusted to produce trustworthy data.

40F3A49133524F849680B2B793A982A1.description: Data integrity means only authorized changes are made only by authorized people.

241F637E7DB24C51A7CEC311E5AA283F.description: The purpose of personal data protection is not to merely protect a person’s data, but to protect the fundamental rights, freedoms, and welfare of persons who are related to that data.

EEBBB78341704428A5BBB04189F1F7E9.description: Data must be protected in processing, transmitting and storage.

49F8BDFE63F24A5D897ABF99E51D57CD.description: Data can be used to help individuals, but it can also be exploited to harm individuals.

1458E24110284A6982F91D87B66DBE4D.description: Data can reveal much about people, their thoughts, and lives; which makes personally identifiable information highly sensitive.

52A4E81E67E54107864FDFCD4C469610.description: Students will analyze existing data security concerns and assess methods to overcome those concerns.

6CC949DBA346439F95F77D853EE127AE.description: Data security deals with the integrity of the data, i.e., the protection from corruption or errors; the privacy of data; and data confidentiality, i.e., it being accessible to only those who have access privilege to it.

F61AA96A703A412BB747035804A3DFFB.description: Devices with limited processing power such as Internet of Things (IoT) devices and control systems in industrial settings may rely almost entirely on network security devices such as firewalls and IPS for protection.

598CAB26B5E347FDA0D41357C62205DB.description: Application layer defenses, such as input validation, check and block potentially harmful message data from getting to the application.

98C96F7D68F94A06AD623D24CA26237D.description: Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) are similar to IDS and also can prevent attacks by blocking messages related to anomalies or signatures.

402A33BB406A42DA9B620776B242B0D0.description: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) work at all layers to identify and raise an alarm when unexpected message patterns (anomalies) or known bad patterns (signatures) are detected (blacklisting). IDS systems can also be configured to block all packets and only allow a select set of valid packets (whitelisting).

FEDB533AEBB94000B6F4EDA839CF5CC6.description: Firewalls work primarily at the network and transport layer by blocking packets with addresses and ports that correspond to unwanted traffic.

514B2563A77F4D73B080B6A00EBA2CCF.description: A packet can be identified by its source address (sending device), source port (sending application on the device), destination address (receiving device), and destination port (receiving application on the device).

6346342072A146A093D6A0BAF2509124.description: Most protocols lack a security component but some protocols build in security. For example, http was designed before security was a major concern while extensions like https explicitly add security to the standard.

C44FE7C38A0D46CCB24847A32DB50523.description: Students will identify and distinguish between the purposes of network security devices and technologies.

1601CC78A9F24D639E5D0D19D5352B13.description: At the application layer, messages sent by the adversary may cause applications to stop working or behave in a way that serves the goals of the adversary, rather than the way they were designed.

75D61BCA9642423399C794D1FE23BCE6.description: At the transport layer, an adversary may disguise their intentions by using port numbers incorrectly or may disrupt the ability of a device to deliver data to the application.

EBE39D6706BF4B7E8189483B8FE6BF06.description: At the network layer, an adversary may do two things, impersonate an address (spoofing) or disrupt communication (Denial of Service).

60E4C067752E4D459141139193A5DB08.description: At the physical/link layer, an adversary who is able to connect to the link can observe, and possibly modify or jam messages on that link.

8E4693E1945C4030829A645B7675A020.description: Students will identify and predict the outcomes of security vulnerabilities at the physical/link layer, the network layer, the transport layer, and the application layer.

2C5D44088DB94683818C08F95C7DC16A.description: An adversary can stay undetected for a long period of time suggesting that early detection is key in preventing a large amount of damage.

A74BC264104749DBA5997EA3EE3981A9.description: An adversary can attack a large number of systems simultaneously, which can impact a large majority of a group of people.

F1964844E38F43F5B461D9423BA597DE.description: By directing an attack at a collection of devices (or even all devices on a network), an adversary can attack multiple devices simultaneously, in hopes of compromising a few select devices.

62721E3A0F1D441394246C00BED50B4F.description: Network mapping and recon tools allow an adversary to gain information on remote systems and an opportunity to get control of the system.

D7E85FB924754108B814E389F305D084.description: Students will analyze how the connected nature of the Internet allows an adversary to reach a large number of devices.

756A2CCDF5A5446DB0F0F7CE020651CA.description: The Internet provides a large attack surface, which offers efficiencies or economies of scale for adversaries.

33BE2D5BBDB94973994F9D85CC3BEC5F.description: Through experiments, an adversary can often learn how proprietary protocols or algorithms work even though the adversary is not an authorized user.

56626D0A9B5D44998A16E2DB295E847F.description: Cryptographic algorithms are either publicly known or proprietary. The use of proprietary cryptographic algorithms is largely discredited, as evidenced by organizations like NIST, which encourages public review of algorithms.

A8A75690A5424479B8BBD192BFC4F5AF.description: When designers rely on secrecy, assuming an adversary cannot compromise the system because the adversary cannot determine how the system works is known as security through obscurity. It is widely accepted that security through obscurity should never be your only security mechanism.

A32622020D1A4A5DB922AE9D48F18F4E.description: Some standards are open standards where the packet format and message exchange rules are available to everyone. In other standards called proprietary standards, the message formats and message exchange rules are only provided to authorized entities.

40867219E48C4D5B863E0C2D46209860.description: Some protocols are proprietary and are available only to authorized users while other protocols are published as formal standards and allow devices from any manufacturer to communicate with each other.

622F7CABDA11412DACEEAF4D512458AA.description: One commonly used protocol is the Domain Name System (DNS) which provides a mechanism to map names like “www.example.com” into numbers (IP addresses), similar to a phonebook that maps names to phone numbers.

04E010EE2F9B49D39A54DB4D47A11387.description: Communication protocols define the rules, types, and formats of messages exchanged between devices and are necessary to allow devices to communicate with each other.

21100235B71C4FBF9D4B01208DBDEBD3.description: Students will explain how network standards and protocols allow different types of devices to communicate.

EC7C28EED44B4C308298A5A58A936B71.description: Internet and device applications (web, text messaging, games, etc.) follow protocols at the application layer (e.g. http, sms, proprietary protocols, etc.).

CDF6221F77434BF9A4FF578B6078C0AC.description: Once a packet arrives at a device, the transport layer uses port numbers to determine which application (web browser, email app, game, etc.) receives the packet, allowing for the reliable delivery of data between a sending and receiving application.

59B19CDFBC954112925A529771FA68A0.description: The network layer connects different types of networks to form larger networks and ultimately the global Internet. It transmits data from one computer to another using packets and logical addressing.

997E376874794C4E8CCE60FC3D7E1458.description: Link layer protocols such as Ethernet, Wifi (e.g., 802.11), and Bluetooth are specific to the physical layer connection and describe how the signals are used to exchange data between the devices.

4801A26A346A490088368459A5ADE03C.description: Physical links include optical cables that send signals using light, cables that send signals using electrical pulses, and wireless networks that send signals over radio waves.

916205496AC54C4C8A2C29DFB9C113A6.description: Networks carry two types of information, those that allow for the controlling of the data and the data itself.

D3DC894C079342148B7BC585B3C45F4E.description: Students will explain how devices use layers to communicate across the Internet and describe the purpose of the layers.

15CF89EED2D441189F445BEAD1FA37C9.description: The Internet is a large, globally distributed network that is divided into layers, governed by protocols, and connects a wide variety of devices.

83A0E8D8FC284EF3B34C0D6A6E9F4B49.description: The only assumption you can safely make is that data and networks are not safe

694E016242E44D0D8D80F3C4041C1737.description: When confronting incorrect assumptions, facing up to cyber attacks is an ongoing, and constantly evolving challenge.

6E3EECAEC1344D00B986FFFE18E05938.description: Incorrect assumptions lead to system failures.

B7F07D33F15F4343B9B005002C95D9CC.description: Key assumptions of systems are things such as whether only valid users are in the system, whether hardware is trusted, whether the software really does what it claims to do.

D8ABC7C37D5B44EB808BD95E4BA7CF6A.description: An assumption in this context is an assertion about the security of a system being designed; it can be a valid or invalid assertion.

30564A2394CF4D188274E50F64CC7FE9.description: Given a scenario, students will identify the assumptions made in the design of the system, evaluate their impact on security, and consider how different assumptions change the security.

8014C4BC26E94F978245A8FEA60A6ECD.description: Identifying and questioning assumptions is a key part of making a system more secure.

F27C25520F6B4A61BDC44470F4276D20.description: Turning off permission causes a security problem.

D9C85AF944284774BE030B9FDEF059CE.description: A secure state is a condition when no subject can access any object in an unauthorized manner.

507223E32077461C94D0C26028947864.description: When something does not work or the system fails, the system must return to a secure state.

433740BF9CDC455F877D5708EA44DDBA.description: Students will define the principle of fail-safe defaults, which restricts how privileges are initialized when a subject or object is created.

5A2300100DEB4ABF8711209BF7619C0E.description: A system's components may be separated and recombined.

4447237744A94A2EB23463AF57037321.description: The principle of modularity says that individual components are capable of executing a unique part of the desired functionality and is achieved through system design. Because of this modular design, security upgrades can happen in one component without having to overhaul the entire system.

22A568AF7F3745B193A1B353DA6AA710.description: Students will recognize that cybersecurity often applies to a system that consists of individual self-sufficient components and the overall security is dependent on the security prosperities of the components.

EDA7FD96019D4E0B8B4BFABDFE6E48AA.description: Data hiding can help prevent users/programmers/processes from updating/changing data in invalid ways or by mistake.

87549D03606D471094BE30DA890313A6.description: Students will know that the principle of data hiding is about allowing only necessary aspects of a data structure or a record to be observed or accessed.

3D887564908147F3B76B04FD6F72A0F2.description: Multiple independent layers require integration and independent management to get the full benefits of layered protection.

2A123641E4024192B9D4BBD9258F7110.description: A layer is a separate level that must be conquered by an attacker to breach a system.

5299B62B973F422380787735E3DC4C0F.description: Students will break down how the principle of layering is a strategy for slowing down an attack because the attacker has to conquer each layer before moving on to the next.

877C960FCA2D457B9A605983996CE4E0.description: Granting only those privileges necessary for a user to accomplish assigned duties improves accountability and limits accidental misuse.

ACADEC7FBF0A40CB80DAC12110221F71.description: Least privilege is the concept and practice of restricting access rights for users, accounts, and computing processes to only those resources absolutely required to perform routine, legitimate activities.

9E7BAB7B0EEA4D8982AF82FF8EF12C1D.description: A privilege is a right for the user to act on managed computer resources.

9AB9E9B917954B3C9B23A3EAF27C00BA.description: Students will define the principle of least privilege, which is about differentiating among types of access control (mandatory, role-based, discretionary, and rule-based access controls) and analyzing which to use for selective restriction of access to a place or other resource.

E5FCD354A6364DED95CD21BE0D215A68.description: Encapsulation allows access or manipulation of the class data in only the ways the designer intended.

3181B111DC5841FB810EC116613538E1.description: Examples of resources are the memory, disk drive, network bandwidth, battery power, and a monitor. It can also be system objects such as shared memory or a linked list data structure.

363714EE562B44398540E1399CB0AC3B.description: Students will explain the importance of encapsulating resources, i.e., creating well-defined interfaces around resources to set rules for how the resources should interact.

3EE1FED05B6648B094D644F37EFBDC28.description: Processes have to use defined communications mediated by the operating system to communicate with other processes.

1F9F611D249C466C898001F891BD9D67.description: Each process has a region of the memory (address space), which only it can access.

23756B89A3694F118819CD17B52AFEE2.description: A process is a program running on a computer.

CE408EC06F484CC0B1E0FD4B3B4E67EF.description: Students will explain that the principle of process isolation prevents tampering or interference from/by other processes.

813E07D46F594A3186B56EAB1A6135B3.description: Communications between domains are allowed only as authorized.

631A6EA3834144F89B07D34D14FA8676.description: A domain refers to a collection of data or instructions that warrant protection.

A4774F0861B4468A841E7350674F7091.description: Students will give examples of the principle of domain separation, which allows for the enforcement of rules governing the entry and use of domains by entities outside the domain.

C5891EE3DB1A475D8B6B8F81CD7EB28B.description: The more you restrict access, processes, resources, and users based on the policy, the more secure the system.

D64E89E6C28F48A4B5376002C5143754.description: Common mechanisms and access should be minimized.

D51E09D727A24C63B3C3D1E804C917E4.description: The human interface should be designed for ease of use, so that users routinely and automatically apply the protection mechanisms correctly.

C7DFCDEF4CF34D189016E4DF323865FE.description: Minimizing the attack surface decreases the opportunity to find an exploitable vulnerability in the system.

ED3C0DFEBE804544858BA7992E42007C.description: The attack surface of a software environment is the sum of the different points where an unauthorized user can try to enter data or to extract data from an environment.

C386B86216F24F15B96F9D05C758930D.description: Students will apply the principle of minimization by decreasing the number of ways in which attackers can exploit a program or device.

AC64A29199BA463097421D3D36E076F2.description: Good and elegant design involves using abstraction.

E75C76E09D4B4CEF8709C72C89AE50F5.description: Abstraction is reducing the complexity of an object down to its essentials in a way that is understandable.

6088A03F9904497599E27DF002021F55.description: Students will use the principle of abstraction to represent complicated concepts more simply and to allow solutions to be transferred to other contexts.

9F4C2DE3153A45B789AE9F746B23B367.description: A simple design incorporates a careful analysis of what is needed.

8E8B8D1AB40B492A87B8C636AF8CEF63.description: Simplicity is also known as “Economy of Mechanism.”

B3D8D57408AD4956891CD92AEEFAC03F.description: Simple designs are easier to understand, maintain and test for security problems.

3EBC72C332744CFDBF5E38CD70D14F52.description: Students will describe the principle of simplicity, which is about ensuring that systems are easy to understand, maintain and test so as to be more secure.

61AF4FB3E1EB435BB107F82F4475573D.description: The simpler you can make the design or implementation of a system, the better you can check whether or not it can be exploited.

127835DC350D4CE6BE789F4B9EF15E45.description: Assuring availability includes prevention, detection, and response mechanisms.

1FE9BD5FF29C4B19A9AE60F71BD148D8.description: There is a tradeoff between 1) confidentiality and integrity and 2) availability.

B1FE4017BB6A437DA1809652194A7830.description: Denial of service attacks are attempts to block availability

BED5664DB726467E8906340400332C2E.description: Availability of information refers to ensuring that authorized parties are able to access the information when needed.

86DED90447B44B0DB96A21D16A52AB68.description: Students will evaluate methods of protecting information and information systems from disruption and destruction.

094F6D2EA2DC4745921923BC93FFF91D.description: Integrity mechanisms include prevention, detection and response mechanisms.

D501C10867FB4098BEC08B9BE7FA6E33.description: Data integrity is the information changing in authorized ways by authorized people, often called authentication.

47B64813D07A4CF5A633A6AE456851D4.description: Assurance is determining how much and in which way to trust a system.

B78E4A64A28A492E89370FA1A5D9DF5B.description: Integrity is the trustworthiness of data or resources.

48826ABE04BF4140962D0FF6F6F8B0FE.description: Students will demonstrate that integrity involves trust and credibility.

74EF4C0543CE471DB2663F20F34BD51C.description: Assuring confidentiality includes prevention, detection, and response mechanisms.

044BE20CF7E94F17BA46C6B9D0468339.description: Hiding is another aspect of confidentiality

1CAF90ED3CC6438D9F0A006A9FABBBEF.description: Cryptography is necessary to ensure confidentiality and integrity.

6030F8E42C3B400DBB300AA97D38FC50.description: File permissions are a mechanism to control access to only those authorized.

DC65372D88BC4091A8EDB15183A7373D.description: Confidentiality is the protection of information from disclosure to unauthorized parties.

4872F7854CB949DF8B8D1F94D7A74A74.description: Students will evaluate methods of keeping information secret from those whom the information should be kept secret.

51EF451D308649E5A863F3883727CA86.description: Cybersecurity relies on confidentiality, integrity, and availability (the CIA triad).

D69781AA0C1145F792F7AB5A27C2DBAE.description: Disclosure of software vulnerabilities to a party other than the software developer is legal and can be harmful.

F497883BD5544F0BA11343E238F100EC.description: Using the anonymity of the internet for behavior that can harm others may not be illegal.

29004224151140C1A18AF06043E43880.description: Technology moves faster than laws can be created to govern it.

9401A04696854CE28A988BCACCAA369C.description: The legal and ethical consequences of cybersecurity practices can be explored through ethical versus malicious (e.g., white/gray/black hat) hacking.

D6406C3D93384AD1952806014F6630DF.description: Students will discuss how even when a cybersecurity practice is legal, it may not be ethical.

9F43E1F544FA4068815FFCDEB8ACE9EC.description: Social responsibility is an ethical theory, in which individuals are accountable for fulfilling their civic duty; the actions of an individual must benefit the whole of society.

9968A03AE3FE473EB042CAFFA52A90AE.description: Ethical obligations are covenants that define a moral course of action and draw a line between right and wrong.

1787A4904F5242738CDEE4A52CB6BE87.description: Students will discuss how ethical obligations to society always coexist with ethical obligations to one’s family, friends, employer, local community, and even oneself.

7FC2E7BAD0834DA8A07D6472D38FC783.description: Security is freedom from potential harm or other unwanted coercive change caused by others.

1BC42262D14F4A72905C73BD67E3B307.description: Resilience is the ability to prepare for and adapt to changing conditions and withstand and recover rapidly from disruptions.

22CFDEFD11F643E4BE76DD4DB2009DBD.description: Autonomy means that every entity is in control of their own thoughts and actions.

69717C1499424008B9F5DA7E04995EF9.description: Transparency is important for trustworthiness and openness in a society, but can come at a risk to privacy and security.

338AF7BEFDD748E394453763BEBB2A02.description: Students will explore the tensions that exist between transparency, autonomy, resilience and security.

4DF84DD18C8A4D7AACD1258D7D494C19.description: Cybersecurity practices are highly complex and variable causing tensions between what the ethical duties are, to whom the ethical concern should be considered, and whose interests should be invested in protecting.

C5E442E556F64DF4A7E1472B212D5F41.description: Security tools were designed to help system administrators and users to improve security, but an adversary can use the same tools to exploit the target for nefarious goals.

9C4C3825AEE44BBDB003F10C36E55C10.description: The designer assumptions and user assumptions could differ. Another way to say this, the user may not know the assumptions of the designer for using the tool, leading the user to use the tool in a way the designer never intended.

886B3FDFFA634820848ACA9B5D7989D7.description: Students will give examples of where/how tools are used in ways that were not intended by the system designer.

5E5D7BDED19142678CCE0A62A9A734A7.description: Cybersecurity requires resources, including time, money, and expertise that also affects technological affordances.

CC3D31E166CA412799D2F8AD0B97957F.description: There are trade-offs concerning the harms and benefits of cybersecurity, including the tensions between ensuring privacy and enabling convenience and usability.

E8A3E5774F3B48AC8D8E1FF8E5309F20.description: Examples in history demonstrate the harms and benefits of cybersecurity from multiple perspectives.

EC45BA6707E94004A871F870E4332ACF.description: Students will discuss how cybersecurity can significantly impact the quality of people’s lives both positively and negatively.

576AD50C42BC4B24ADCC50B0526E748E.description: Ethical reflection and judgement are required in considering the potential harms, benefits, and trade-offs involved in cybersecurity.

3106242E04364650A325DC9D056BAD53.description: Professional codes of ethics convey the expected conduct of cybersecurity professionals.

76137C6D08234D508039F491EC94C845.description: Cybersecurity laws reflect values about national security, economic security, welfare of citizens, domestic law and order, and legitimacy of government.

35729ABA0BDA4D349C5E48257210D413.description: Cyberwarfare, cybersecurity and privacy affect and are affected by institutions, political structures and policies.

740ED47553C34E968F131DF4355E1222.description: Institution refers to informal norms, shared understandings, and formal doctrines that constrain and prescribe actors' interactions with one another.

EA8AE0FB200443D693503D10469666F3.description: Political structure refers to institutions, their relations to and interactions with each other, and the laws and norms present in political systems in such a way that they constitute the political landscape of the political entity.

FFA2B54329374B918A3B67580B0FF22E.description: Students will understand how the role of values and ethics affects political structures, laws, and policy decisions as it relates to cybersecurity.

F2B0BFD313EF4FB3B48DCE79A5328C45.description: Different communities and societies have different foundational social goals and values that impact their behaviors concerning technology.

7E047791D4FD471AA3282090516401D2.description: Values concerning how to engage in cyber technologies can and do compete during the creative process of designing the technology and its adoption.

365946048D894EC1BEA5585CC762E717.description: Cybersecurity ethics is an expression of values by the designers and users.

803E4A001FCA417C9F11F2B102985E83.description: Societies are groups of individuals characterized by common interests/values that are perpetuated by persistent social interaction.

9060CF6ED6E347CDA2D106E29E59A6A3.description: Students will analyze online and offline behaviors in societies, i.e., themselves, peers, families, communities, and countries, and deduce the values that govern these behaviors.

2A489F25B933459C86C20089071AB7FE.description: Social goals reflect the foundational values held by society; these core societal values are reflected in cybersecurity choices.
